triggers.name: DFSR Event Log: number of critical errors in the last {$DFSRLOG_PERIOD} > {$DFSRLOGCRITICAL_MAX} (errors={ITEM.LASTVALUE})

items.name: DFSR Event Log: number of the last error events

triggers.name: DFSR Event Log: number of errors in the last {$DFSRLOG_PERIOD} > {$DFSRLOGERRORS_MAX} (errors={ITEM.LASTVALUE})

items.name: DFSR Event Log: number of the last warning events

triggers.name: DFSR Event Log: number of warnings in the last {$DFSRLOG_PERIOD} > {$DFSRLOGWARNINGS_MAX} (warnings={ITEM.LASTVALUE})
DFSR Monitoring Provider Version was changed
There are no replication groups for the server
The server was excluded from one or more RGs

items.name: DFS Replication service state
items.description:
Service Starting (0)
Service Running (1)
Service Degraded (2)
Service Shutting Down (3)
Stopped (100)
Not Found (101)

triggers.name: State of DFS Replication service became 'Degraded'

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' was disabled by schedule
trigger_prototypes.description: Distributed File System (DFS) Replication connections are the logical partnerships between members in a replication group. The DFS Replication service uses the Remote Procedure Call (RPC) protocol to communicate between servers. By default, DFS Replication creates connections with the recommended schedule and bandwidth configuration: full bandwidth, and 24 hours per day, seven days per week availability.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' was disabled
trigger_prototypes.description:
You can enable or disable replication with specific members of a replication group. However, it is important to understand the ramifications of doing so. After a disabled member is enabled, the member must complete an initial replication of the replicated folder. Initial replication will cause about 1 KB of data to be transferred for each file or folder in the replicated folder, and any updated or new files present on the member will be moved to the DfsrPrivate\PreExisting folder on the member, and it will be replaced with authoritative files from another member.
If all members are disabled for a replicated folder, then the first member that is enabled will automatically be made the primary member. If the discretionary access control list (DACL) on the local path for this member contains any inherited access-control entries (ACE), these ACEs will be converted to explicit ACEs with the same permissions so that all members will have the same DACL on the replicated folder root.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' was enabled
trigger_prototypes.description:
You can enable or disable replication with specific members of a replication group. However, it is important to understand the ramifications of doing so. After a disabled member is enabled, the member must complete an initial replication of the replicated folder. Initial replication will cause about 1 KB of data to be transferred for each file or folder in the replicated folder, and any updated or new files present on the member will be moved to the DfsrPrivate\PreExisting folder on the member, and it will be replaced with authoritative files from another member.
If all members are disabled for a replicated folder, then the first member that is enabled will automatically be made the primary member. If the discretionary access control list (DACL) on the local path for this member contains any inherited access-control entries (ACE), these ACEs will be converted to explicit ACEs with the same permissions so that all members will have the same DACL on the replicated folder root.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' state
item_prototypes.description:
The current connection state.
Connecting (0)
Online (1)
Offline (2)
In Error (3)
Outbound connections are created on demand after the partner establishes a connection. The DFSR service cannot detect when an outbound connection has been deleted; by default, it waits for 12 hours idle time before determining that the connection has been lost.
Inbound connections persist as long as they are configured.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' became 'Connecting'
trigger_prototypes.description:
Outbound connections are created on demand after the partner establishes a connection. The DFSR service cannot detect when an outbound connection has been deleted; by default, it waits for 12 hours idle time before determining that the connection has been lost.
Inbound connections persist as long as they are configured.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' became 'In Error'
trigger_prototypes.description:
Outbound connections are created on demand after the partner establishes a connection. The DFSR service cannot detect when an outbound connection has been deleted; by default, it waits for 12 hours idle time before determining that the connection has been lost.
Inbound connections persist as long as they are configured.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': connection '{#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME}' became 'Offline'
trigger_prototypes.description:
Outbound connections are created on demand after the partner establishes a connection. The DFSR service cannot detect when an outbound connection has been deleted; by default, it waits for 12 hours idle time before determining that the connection has been lost.
Inbound connections persist as long as they are configured.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): total bytes received
item_prototypes.description: Total Bytes Received shows the total number of bytes received on the connection. The bytes received value includes file data and replication metadata.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): total files received
item_prototypes.description: Total Files Received shows the number of files that were received on the connection.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): size of files received
item_prototypes.description: Size of Files Received shows the uncompressed size (in bytes) of the files received on this connection. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had DFS Replication compression not been used.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): compressed size of files received
item_prototypes.description: Compressed Size of Files Received shows the compressed size of files (in bytes) received on the connection.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): bytes received per second
item_prototypes.description: Bytes Received Per Second shows an estimate of the average number of bytes that were received each second over the past 30 seconds.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): RDC number of riles received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Number of Files Received shows the number files that were received on this connection.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): RDC size of files received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Size of Files Received shows the uncompressed size (in bytes) of files received with remote differential compression (RDC) for this connection. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had neither compression nor RDC been used. This is not the actual number of bytes received over the network.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): RDC compressed size of files received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Compressed Size of Files Received shows the compressed size (in bytes) of files received with remote differential compression (RDC) for this connection. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had RDC not been used. This is not the actual number of bytes received over the network.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): RDC bytes received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Bytes Received shows the bytes that were received on this connection while replicating files using remote differential compression (RDC). This is the actual bytes received over the network without the networking protocol overhead.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}' ({#RCPARTNER}): bandwidth savings using DFS replication
item_prototypes.description: Bandwidth Savings Using DFS Replication shows the percentage of bandwidth that was saved by the DFS Replication service for this connection using a combination of remote differential compression (RDC) and other compression technologies that minimize network bandwidth use. For example, a value of 20 indicates that the DFS Replication service used 20% less bandwidth than it would have used if it had transmitted the entire files uncompressed over the network.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': partner '{#PARTNERNAME}' WMI check failed using '{#NTACCOUNT}' account

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': backlog ({#SSERVERNAME}>{#RSERVERNAME})
item_prototypes.description: Backlog size for outgoing files

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': staging files generated
item_prototypes.description: Staging Files Generated shows the number of times replicated files and folders were staged by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service stages files and folders in a staging folder before they are replicated, and automatically cleans up the staging folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': staging bytes generated
item_prototypes.description: Staging Bytes Generated shows the total size (in bytes) of replicated files and folders in the staging folder created by the DFS Replication service since last restart and is monotonically increasing counter. The DFS Replication service stages files and folders in the staging folder before they are replicated, and automatically cleans up the staging folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': staging files cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Staging Files Cleaned up shows the number of files and folders that were cleaned up from the staging folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service stages files and folders in the staging folder before they are replicated, and automatically cleans up the staging folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': staging bytes cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Staging Bytes Cleaned up shows the total size (in bytes) of the files and folders that were cleaned up from the staging folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service stages files and folders in the staging folder before they are replicated, and automatically cleans up the staging folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': staging space in use
item_prototypes.description: Staging Space In Use shows the total size (in bytes) of the files and folders currently in the staging folder used by the DFS Replication service. This counter will fluctuate as staging space is reclaimed. The DFS Replication service stages files and folders in the staging folder before they are replicated, and automatically cleans up the staging folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict files generated
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Files Generated shows the number of files and folders in this replicated folder that were moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': there were >{$CONFLICTSGENERATED_CHANGE_AVERAGE} lost conflicts in {$CONFLICTSGENERATED_PERIOD} (conflicts={ITEM.LASTVALUE})
trigger_prototypes.description:
The DFS Replication service detected that a file was changed on multiple servers. A conflict resolution algorithm was used to determine the winning file. The losing file was moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder.
Monitoring this performance counter enables administrators to keep track of the number of replication conflicts generated for replicated folders on the monitored computer.
Frequent conflicts indicate that files in a replicated folder are frequently being modified on multiple servers in a short period. When multiple users need to modify the same files at the same time on different servers, use the file check-out feature of Windows SharePoint Services to ensure that only one user is working on a file.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': there were >{$CONFLICTSGENERATED_CHANGE_WARNING} lost conflicts in {$CONFLICTSGENERATED_PERIOD}  (conflicts={ITEM.LASTVALUE})
trigger_prototypes.description:
The DFS Replication service detected that a file was changed on multiple servers. A conflict resolution algorithm was used to determine the winning file. The losing file was moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder.
Monitoring this performance counter enables administrators to keep track of the number of replication conflicts generated for replicated folders on the monitored computer.
Frequent conflicts indicate that files in a replicated folder are frequently being modified on multiple servers in a short period. When multiple users need to modify the same files at the same time on different servers, use the file check-out feature of Windows SharePoint Services to ensure that only one user is working on a file.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict bytes generated
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Bytes Generated shows the total size (in bytes) of the files and folders in this replicated folder that were moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict files cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Files Cleaned up shows the number the conflict loser files and folders that were deleted from the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict bytes cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Bytes Cleaned up shows the total size (in bytes) of the conflict loser files and folders that were deleted from the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict space in use
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Space in Use shows the total size (in bytes) of the conflict loser files and folders currently in the Conflict and Deleted folder used by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict folder cleanups completed
item_prototypes.description: Conflict Folder Cleanups Completed shows the number of times conflict loser files and folders in the Conflict and Deleted folder were deleted by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service automatically detects and resolves conflicts encountered in replicated folders and moves the losing version to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': file installs succeeded
item_prototypes.description: File Installs Succeeded shows the number of files that were successfully received from sending members and installed locally on this server. The DFS Replication service replicates staged files into the staging folder, uncompresses them in the Installing folder, and renames them to the target location. The second and third steps of this process are known as installing the file.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': file installs retried
item_prototypes.description: File Installs Retried shows the number of file installs that are being retried due to sharing violations or other errors encountered when installing the files. The DFS Replication service replicates staged files into the staging folder, uncompresses them in the Installing folder, and renames them to the target location. The second and third steps of this process are known as installing the file.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': updates dropped
item_prototypes.description: Updates Dropped shows the number of redundant file replication update records that were ignored by the DFS Replication service because they did not change the replicated file or folder. For example, dropped updates can occur when access control lists (ACLs) are overwritten with identical ACLs on a file or folder.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted files generated
item_prototypes.description: Deleted Files Generated shows the number of replicated deleted files and folders that were moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder after they were deleted from a replicated folder on a sending member. The DFS Replication service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted bytes generated
item_prototypes.description: Deleted Bytes Generated shows the total size (in bytes) of replicated deleted files and folders that were moved to the Conflict and Deleted folder after they were deleted from a replicated folder on a sending member. The DFS Replication service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted files cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Deleted Files Cleaned up shows the number of replicated deleted files and folders that were cleaned up from the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted bytes cleaned up
item_prototypes.description: Deleted Bytes Cleaned up shows the total size (in bytes) of replicating deleted files and folders (in bytes) that were cleaned up from the Conflict and Deleted folder by the DFS Replication service. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted space in use
item_prototypes.description: Deleted Space in Use shows the total size (in bytes) of the deleted files and folders currently in the Conflict and Deleted folder used by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service detects remote deletes from its sending partner and moves the file or folder to the Conflict and Deleted folder. The service automatically cleans up the Conflict and Deleted folder when it exceeds a pre-configured threshold of the quota.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': total files received
item_prototypes.description: Total Files Received shows the number of files that were received by this replicated folder.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': size of files received
item_prototypes.description: Size of Files Received shows the uncompressed size (in bytes) of the files received for this replicated folder. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had DFS Replication compression not been used.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': compressed size of files received
item_prototypes.description: Compressed Size of Files Received shows the compressed size (in bytes) of files received for this replicated folder.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': RDC number of files received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Number of Files Received shows the number files that were received for this replicated folder.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': RDC size of files received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Size of Files Received shows the uncompressed size (in bytes) of the files received with remote differential compression (RDC) for this replicated folder. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had neither compression nor RDC been used. This is not the actual bytes received over the network.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': RDC compressed size of files received
item_prototypes.description: RDC Compressed Size of Files Received shows the compressed size (in bytes) of the files received with remote differential compression (RDC) for this replicated folder. This is the number of bytes that would have been received had RDC not been used. This is not the actual bytes received over the network.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': bandwidth savings using DFS replication
item_prototypes.description: Bandwidth Savings Using DFS Replication shows the percentage of bandwidth that was saved by the DFS Replication service for this replicated folder using a combination of remote differential compression (RDC) and other compression technologies that minimize network bandwidth. For example, a value of 20 indicates that the DFS Replication service used 20% less bandwidth than it would have used if it had transmitted the entire files uncompressed over the network.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': Conflict and Deleted area free space < {$CONFLICTDIRPFREE_MIN}% ({ITEM.LASTVALUE} left)
trigger_prototypes.description: Monitoring the space utilization of the Conflict and Deleted area helps ensure that there is enough space to store replication conflicts and files deleted from replicated folders on the monitored computer. You can view a log of conflict files and their original file names by viewing the ConflictandDeletedManifest.xml file in the DfsrPrivate folder. Large amounts of used conflict space indicate that files in a replicated folder are frequently being modified on multiple servers in a short period. When multiple users need to modify the same files at the same time on different servers, use the file check-out feature of Windows SharePoint Services to ensure that only one user is working on a file.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': conflict quota was set to {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': enabled
item_prototypes.description:
Replicated folders that are disabled do not replicate and may be out of sync with other members of the replication group. This occurs when an administrator disables the folder, usually to conduct maintenance.
CAUTION: After enabling a replicated folder, DFS Replication performs the initial replication by using the primary member’s files as authoritative regardless of the age, potentially overwriting newer files.
TIP: To prevent this issue from occurring in the future, disable replication connections instead of replicated folders.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}' was disabled
trigger_prototypes.description:
Replicated folders that are disabled do not replicate and may be out of sync with other members of the replication group. This occurs when an administrator disables the folder, usually to conduct maintenance.
CAUTION: After enabling a replicated folder, DFS Replication performs the initial replication by using the primary member’s files as authoritative regardless of the age, potentially overwriting newer files.
TIP: To prevent this issue from occurring in the future, disable replication connections instead of replicated folders.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}' was enabled
trigger_prototypes.description:
Replicated folders that are disabled do not replicate and may be out of sync with other members of the replication group. This occurs when an administrator disables the folder, usually to conduct maintenance.
CAUTION: After enabling a replicated folder, DFS Replication performs the initial replication by using the primary member’s files as authoritative regardless of the age, potentially overwriting newer files.
TIP: To prevent this issue from occurring in the future, disable replication connections instead of replicated folders.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': 'read-only' mode
item_prototypes.description:
A read-only replicated folder is a replicated folder on a particular member in which users cannot add or change files. This is convenient for read-only folders that you want to keep up-to-date with a central server (or servers). For example, software installation folders, or folders that contain published reports or documents. Read-only replicated folders are also used by read-only domain controllers (RODCs) to keep the SYSVOL shared folder updated while preventing local changes.
Read-only replicated folders can be updated only with content from a read-write member of the replication group. All other attempts to write to the folder will fail. This includes performing an authoritative restore operation using a backup program.
WARNING: When you make a replicated folder read-only, DFS Replication overwrites any content on the read-only member that has not yet replicated back to a read-write member. For this reason, it is a good idea to backup the folder, create a diagnostic report of replication and check the replication backlog before you make a replicated folder that contains existing content read-only.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}' was set to 'read-only' mode
trigger_prototypes.description:
A read-only replicated folder is a replicated folder on a particular member in which users cannot add or change files. This is convenient for read-only folders that you want to keep up-to-date with a central server (or servers). For example, software installation folders, or folders that contain published reports or documents. Read-only replicated folders are also used by read-only domain controllers (RODCs) to keep the SYSVOL shared folder updated while preventing local changes.
Read-only replicated folders can be updated only with content from a read-write member of the replication group. All other attempts to write to the folder will fail. This includes performing an authoritative restore operation using a backup program.
WARNING: When you make a replicated folder read-only, DFS Replication overwrites any content on the read-only member that has not yet replicated back to a read-write member. For this reason, it is a good idea to backup the folder, create a diagnostic report of replication and check the replication backlog before you make a replicated folder that contains existing content read-only.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}' was set to 'read-write' mode
trigger_prototypes.description:
A read-only replicated folder is a replicated folder on a particular member in which users cannot add or change files. This is convenient for read-only folders that you want to keep up-to-date with a central server (or servers). For example, software installation folders, or folders that contain published reports or documents. Read-only replicated folders are also used by read-only domain controllers (RODCs) to keep the SYSVOL shared folder updated while preventing local changes.
Read-only replicated folders can be updated only with content from a read-write member of the replication group. All other attempts to write to the folder will fail. This includes performing an authoritative restore operation using a backup program.
WARNING: When you make a replicated folder read-only, DFS Replication overwrites any content on the read-only member that has not yet replicated back to a read-write member. For this reason, it is a good idea to backup the folder, create a diagnostic report of replication and check the replication backlog before you make a replicated folder that contains existing content read-only.

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': redundancy
item_prototypes.description: Number of replication partners which store the folder in 'Normal' state

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': redundancy fail, no replicas in 'Normal' state found on any partner
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted files saving was disabled
trigger_prototypes.description: Indicates whether the member computer deletes files and folders immediately following inbound replication. If this parameter has a value of $False, the member moves deleted files and folders to the ConflictAndDeleted folder when the deletion replicates inbound. The originating server always deletes files without preservation. You can use the Restore-DfsrPreservedFiles cmdlet to restore deleted files while they still exist in the ConflictAndDeleted folder. If this parameter has a value of $True, when a replicating member replicates a deletion, it deletes the local copy of the file immediately. If you do not specify this parameter, by default, DFS Replication preserves deleted files.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': deleted files saving was enabled
trigger_prototypes.description: Indicates whether the member computer deletes files and folders immediately following inbound replication. If this parameter has a value of $False, the member moves deleted files and folders to the ConflictAndDeleted folder when the deletion replicates inbound. The originating server always deletes files without preservation. You can use the Restore-DfsrPreservedFiles cmdlet to restore deleted files while they still exist in the ConflictAndDeleted folder. If this parameter has a value of $True, when a replicating member replicates a deletion, it deletes the local copy of the file immediately. If you do not specify this parameter, by default, DFS Replication preserves deleted files.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': stage free space < {$STAGEDIRPFREE_MIN}% ({ITEM.LASTVALUE} left)
trigger_prototypes.description:
Optimizing the size of the staging folder can improve performance and reduce the likelihood of replication failing. When adjusting the size of the staging folder, consider the following factors.
If a staging folder quota is configured to be too small, DFS Replication might consume additional CPU and disk resources to regenerate the staged files. Replication might also slow down, or even stop, because the lack of staging space can effectively limit the number of concurrent transfers with partners.
For the initial replication of existing data on the primary member, the staging folder quota must be large enough so that replication can continue even if multiple large files remain in the staging folder because partners cannot promptly download the files.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': stage quota was set to {ITEM.LASTVALUE}

item_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state
item_prototypes.description:
The current replicated folder state for this member.
Uninitialized (0)
Initialized (1)
Initial Sync (2)
Auto Recovery (3)
Normal (4)
In Error (5)

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state became 'Auto Recovery'
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state became 'In Error'
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state became 'Initialized'
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state became 'Initial Sync'
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RF '{#RGNAME}\{#RFNAME}': state became 'Uninitialized'
trigger_prototypes.description: The state of a replicated folder can be one of the following: uninitialized, initialized, initial sync, auto recovery, normal, or in error. When first configured, a replicated folder moves to the initialized or initial sync state, depending on whether the server is defined as the primary member of the replicated folder. If the server is defined as a primary member, Distributed File System Replication (DFSR) automatically initializes the folder. In addition, content within the folder is authoritative. That is, the content will win on conflict with another member.

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': default shedule was set to 'no replication' at all

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': inbound connections
item_prototypes.description: Number of inbound connections from partners within the replication group. Disabled connections are included.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': outbound connections
item_prototypes.description: Number of outbound connections to partners within the replication group. Disabled connections are included.

item_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': number of folders
item_prototypes.description: Number of replicated folders of the replication group that are hosted on this computer

trigger_prototypes.name: RG '{#RGNAME}': no RFs found on this server
RG '{#RGNAME}': one or more RFs were added to this server
RG '{#RGNAME}': one or more RFs were removed from this server
RG '{#RGNAME}': no connections found for the group

discovery_rules.name: DFS Replication Service Volumes PerfCounters LLD

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#RVNAME}': USN journal records read
item_prototypes.description: USN Journal Records Read shows the number of update sequence number (USN) journal records that were read by the DFS Replication service.

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#RVNAME}': USN journal records accepted
item_prototypes.description: USN Journal Records Accepted shows the number of update sequence number (USN) journal records that were processed by the DFS Replication service. The DFS Replication service processes all USN journal records for replicated content on a volume and ignores records for non-replicated files and folders on the volume.

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#RVNAME}': USN journal unread (percentage)
item_prototypes.description: USN Journal Unread Percentage shows the percent of the update sequence number (USN) journal that has not yet been read and processed by the DFS Replication service. A journal wrap will occur if this counter reaches 100.

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#RVNAME}': database commits
item_prototypes.description: Database Commits shows the number of database commit operations performed by the DFS Replication service. This counter indicates how intensive the DFS Replication service is from a database perspective.

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#RVNAME}': database lookups
item_prototypes.description: Database Lookups shows the number of database search operations performed by the DFS Replication service This counter indicates how intensive the DFS Replication service is from a database perspective.

item_prototypes.name: Volume '{#VOLUMENAME}': state
item_prototypes.description:
The current volume state.
Initialized (0)
Shutting Down (1)
In Error (2)
Auto Recovery (3)
